contraindications: Contraindicated in all cases of early menstruation.
Contraindicated in all cases of Blood Heat.
Do not use unless there is firm, stubborn accumulation.
Caution with Qi and Blood Deficiency.
interactions: Use with caution for patients taking anticoagulants such as heparin, warfarin (Coumadin) and enoxaparin (Lovenox) or antiplatelet drugs such as aspirin, dipyridamole (Persantine) and clopidogrel (Plavix) as concurrent use may have an additive or synergistic effect.

useCases: Food Stagnation with abdominal distention, fullness and pain.
Food Stagnation with abdominal distention, fullness, and pain with Qi Deficiency.
Stagnant Qi with chest and abdominal fullness and pain.
Menstrual problems due to Qi and Blood Stagnation, especially depression, painful abdominal masses, dysmenorrhea, amenorrhea and a wiry pulse.
Qi and Blood Stagnation with clumping and accumulations leading to pain with distending pain in the chest, epigastrium and abdomen, amenorrhea, dysmenorrhea, uterine myoma and ovarian cysts.
Hepatosplenomegaly with distention, pain and immobile, palpable epigastric, sub costal and abdominal masses. (only for strong patients)
Hepatosplenomegaly with distention, pain, and immobile, palpable epigastric, sub costal, and abdominal masses with Heat. (only for strong patients)
Epigastric distention and hardness of the right rib cage.
Epigastric distention and hardness of the left rib cage.
Abdominal pain due to Qi Stagnation.
Abdominal fullness and pain due to Qi Deficiency.

notes: Some sources consider this herb primarily as an anti-cancer herb and is considered one of the most effective anti-cancer herbs.
It is used with Rz. Sparganii #{SanLeng} San Leng for cervical cancer.
It is used as a single herb for late stage cervical cancer during menses.
This is a weaker Blood Invigorator than San Leng, but a stronger Qi mover.
It's primary action is in the abdomen, flanks and hypochondrium.
It regulates Qi, increases appetite, breaks up Blood Stasis, relieves pain and stops dysentery.
It removes Phlegm and treats globus hystericus.

This herb is dry-fried for Liver diseases, simmered for diseases of the Heart and Spleen channels and roasted with goat or chicken for regulating menstruation for which it is used with Four Substances Decoction #{../Herb Formulas copy/SiWuTang} Si Wu Tang.
Local injection of the volatile oil necrotizes the tumor and causes it to come off without affecting the surrounding tissue.
Dry-fried Rz. Curcumae Chao E Zhu is suitable for more ordinary use than firm, stubborn accumulation.
Vinegar Rz. Curcumae Cu E Zhu is better able to enter the blood level of the Liver channel and its ability to disperse Stasis and stop pain is enhanced.

Both E Zhu and Rz. Curcumae Longae #{JiangHuang} Jiang Huang are warm, acrid and bitter and both break up Blood Stasis and move Qi to stop pain. E Zhu more strongly breaks up Blood Stasis and reduces accumulations while Jiang Huang moves on the Interior and Exterior to treat Wind Bi.
